Award.AwardTitle: Active Dynamic Continuum Tails for Maneuvering and Stabilizing Legged Robots

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Results of this research will provide an opportunity to create robotic tails that are capable of augmenting a legged robot's ability for agile and robust terrain traversal in unstructured hazardous environments. The research will impact applications from search and rescue to reconnaissance to exploring hazardous and dangerous environments, in which robots must move effectively in unstructured terrains. Legged robots can better traverse these unstructured environments compared to wheeled or tracked systems due to the legs' use of discrete ground contact points. This project's primary impact stems from the tail's improvements to a legged robot's stability and maneuverability. This will lead to faster search and rescue or exploration of dangerous environments, allowing these legged robots to augment and exceed human capabilities. In terms of educational impact, this research will: (1) provide support for engineering graduate and undergraduate students, (2) be developed into case studies for university-level courses, and (3) be used in demonstrations for K-12 students. Minorities and underrepresented groups will be targeted for outreach and participation.

The research objective of this award is to study how biomimetic continuum tails can dynamically stabilize and maneuver legged mobile robots moving at high speeds. Field robots are limited in how they may respond to unforeseen dynamic disturbances in unstructured hazardous environments and how they may change their direction without modifying gait and slowing down. With a continuum tail, the required forces and moments to stabilize and maneuver the robot can be applied by dynamic tail motions instead of using the legs, torso or arms. This research will study algorithms to map the required forces and moments into continuum tail control inputs to stabilize and maneuver a legged robot, and derive dynamic models to predict the tail's dynamic forces and moments to enable task planning. Deliverables include dynamic modeling, task planning algorithms and design paradigms of intelligent robotic tails, an experimental validation with a test platform of the tail mechanism and simulations of legged locomotion, dissemination of research results, engineering student education, engineering research experiences for students and science teachers, and new engineering curriculum development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported research studying how biologically inspired robotic tails could be used to maneuver and stabilize legged robots. Much of the existing research into maneuvering and stabilizing legged robots has focused on using the legs to achieve these goals. Looking to nature, numerous animals use their tails in a variety of ways to assist their legs during locomotion. However, prior research into robotic tails has focused on simple single-mass pendulum-like structures, instead of robotic structures that bend like biological tails.

Serpentine robots, which are comprised of numerous similar links connected together, were used to approximate the continuous deformation of biological tails. Three novel serpentine robot designs were conceptualized, designed and implemented as part of this project, shown in Fig. 1: the Roll-Revolute-Revolute Robotic Tail, the Universal-Spatial Robotic Tail, and the Discrete Modular Serpentine Tail.

The four main goals of this project were to: (1) derive mathematical models to predict the loading a robotic tail would apply to a mobile robot, (2) determine how tail motion profiles affect the motion of bipedal and quadrupedal robots, (3) create methods of planning and controlling tail motions to implement desired maneuvering and stabilizing behaviors, and (4) experimentally validate these analyses using a physical prototype of the tails.

For goal 1, dynamics models for each of the tail designs were studied accounting for the various sources of loading within the tail (such as inertia, dampening, elasticity, gearing, actuation, gravity, friction). These models were subsequently used to study the tail’s loading capabilities in goals 2 and 3.

For goal 2, simulated quadrupedal and bipedal robots were tested in conjunction with the simulated robotic tail structures to assess the impact of various tail properties (such as mass distribution and length) on the resulting behavior in the legged robot.

For goal 3, methods of calculating tail motions to implement desired maneuvering and stabilization behaviors in both the quadruped and biped were determined. For quadruped and biped maneuvering, a bending tail motion was implemented to change the yaw-angle heading of the legged robot. For quadruped stabilization, a rolling tail motion was implemented to counteract a destabilizing roll moment applied to the quadruped. For bipedal stabilization, a cyclical rolling tail motion was implemented to prevent the biped from tipping when one of its legs is lifted.

For goal 4, prototypes of all three robotic tails were implemented (Fig. 1), and the loading that they generated while moving was measured using a six-axis load cell. This measured loading was compared to the simulated loading, and conclusions were drawn regarding the accuracy of the tail models. A hardware-in-the-loop setup (shown in Fig. 2) was also used to connect the physical tail subsystem prototype to the simulated legged robot subsystem to observe the impact the prototype’s tail loading had on the simulated legged robot behaviors. Both maneuvering and stabilization functionalities were validated.  

The Intellectual Merit of this research stems from its connection of the previously separate fields of robotic tails and serpentine robots to implement multi-functional, bioinspired robotic tails. Furthermore, analyses generated as part of this research demonstrated the superiority of biomimetic articulated robotic tail designs over prior pendulum-like approaches. The Broader Impact of this research aims to improve the understanding of how robotic tails may be incorporated into legged robot designs to improve the performance of legged robots while simultaneously reducing the complexity required of leg design and control. In addition, this grant supported the work of several graduate student researchers and educational outreach efforts by the PI to a wide range of students and the public.
